titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

div.p: The essential faiths of mankind show a surprising power of surviving the dogma on which they are supposed to rest.

p.hi: The "Times prints the short letter which I wrote at Bishopthorpe in answer to the Bishop of S
Alban's. It will no doubt be ignored by the "Church Times", which none the less gives great prominence to the most offensive paragraph of the Bishop's letter

body.p: Edgar Dobie wrote me a quaint affectionate letter in which he tells me that he has 'sometimes to champion my cause â€“ often against very ordinary people, who do not wish to reason, but who oppose on principal, & certainly will not be convinced.'

'I have defended to the best of my ability, and have wished you could be there personally. I am always comforted when I say to myself. "They do not know him and I do; & I love him because I know him". That is a touching expression of loyalty from an old Durham chorister. I do not mind much the misrepresentation & insult of the 'Church Times' on my own account, but I do regret the distress & disturbance of mind caused to so many persons, clergy & laity, who do not know how far partisanship will carry men, & are at the mercy of what they read. Probably the continuing denunciation of the Bishop in the newspaper which they read regularly with religious devotion does affect their minds, & make episcopal government more difficult.
